repository.corpname: Columbia University.Rare Book and Manuscript Library,

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Prendergast received his Ph.D. at Columbia in 1954 and then went to the University of Chicago, returning to Columbia as a professor in 1962. He chaired the Columbia astronomy department from 1978 to 1984, retiring in 2000 with a long trail of successful young theorists in his wake. Prendergast was an icon in the field of dynamics of many-body systems. He also was well known for a series of papers in the 1960s and 1970s, written with Geoffrey and Margaret Burbidge, on understanding the rotation curves of galaxies. Numerous theoretical studies of the structure of galaxies followed, and he was a pioneer in the study of X-ray binary systems. In addition to Prendergast's professional accomplishments, he was also a skilled pianist and an avid sailor. During his long career, Prendergast became famous for using yellow legal pads, on which he had scrawled analyses of many problems in astronomical dynamics. His classes were renowned for the exactitude of his standards and the high percentage of faculty in attendance. During one year, regularly attending faculty outnumbered students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, manuscripts, lectures, notes, and printed materials of Kevin H. Prendergast, a prominent astronomer who worked in the fields off dynamics of many-body systems, the rotation curves of galaxies, and X-ray binary systems.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into 12 series:

list.item: Series III: Dynamical Systems and Applied Mathematics
Series V: Applications of Hydrodynamics and Rarified Gas Dynamics

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is located off-site. You will need to request this material from the Rare Book and Manuscript Library at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance to use the collection in the Rare Book and Manuscript Library reading room.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Kevin H. Prendergast Papers; Box and Folder; Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University Library.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. Permission to publish material from the collection must be requested from the Curator of Manuscripts/University Archivist, Rare Book and Manuscript Library (RBML). The RBML approves permission to publish that which it physically owns; the responsibility to secure copyright permission rests with the patron.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.2: Dynamics of Galaxies: General
Stochastic star formation in disk galaxies (mathematical description of a game theory)
Subseries II.3: Dynamics of Galaxies: Spiral Galaxies
Thin gas disk: asymptotic theory of spiral arms (warped disk as finite system of coupled rings)
Subseries II.4: Dynamics of Galaxies: Barred Spiral Galaxies
Barred spiral galaxies (I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII), (1960s, 1970s)
Barred spiral galaxies—some plots & shock waves in barred spiral galaxies
Theoretical studies of gas flow in barred spiral galaxies
Barred spiral galaxies: material for a talk based on a paper on “Theoretical studies of gas flows in barred spiral galaxies” by K. Prendergast
Talk given by Kevin Prendergast on barred spiral galaxies, 1982
Subseries II.5: Dynamics of Galaxies: Dwarf Elliptical Galaxies (and Elliptical Galaxies)
Dwarf elliptical galaxies--analytical approximation (two-fluid with gravity)
Modeling the formation of elliptical and dwarf galaxies using a spheroidal two-fluid system with self-gravity
Numerical Simulations of the Formation of Dwarf Ellipticals (I,II, III, IV, V)
Marseille numerical simulation results and some theoretical analysis of those models
Marseille numerical simulation results performed at Marseille Observatory, France (collaborators Lia Athanassoula et al.), 1988
Numerical models (including programs) and results for one-dimensional two-fluid (Cartesian grid) and Marseille models
Dwarf galaxies formation models (Marseille 1994) and other numerical modeling results (including programs)
Various numerical simulation results of the Marseille collaboration [mostly in the form of diagrams]
Marseille Observatory simulation results used for Columbia Astrofest talk, 1996
Dwarf elliptical galaxy formation, talk given at Columbia, 1990
Subseries II.6: Dynamics of Galaxies: Star-Gas Interactions in Galaxies

3-fluid model (gas, high mass star, low mass star)
Talk given at European Southern Observatory, Munich, Germany
Escape of stars from clusters: statistical mechanical approach, 1980s
X-ray generation in accretion disk in binary systems, gas streams in close binary systems
Rotating asteroid (I, II, III, IV, V), 1950
Subseries II.10: Few- and N-body Problems, and Celestial Mechanics
Statistics of the gravitational three- and four-body problems
Subseries II.11: Hydrodynamics, Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics, and Gas-Kinetic Theory
A series of analytic studies (notebooks I-VI) on hydrodynamics, as moment equations of the Boltzmann equation
Singularities of one dimensional hydrodynamic system using pseudo Liouville equation
Gravity in the BGK scheme for hydrodynamics
Solution of the Krook equation at shock
Collisional hydrodynamic scheme (CHS)—theoretical derivation of the method
Burger’s equation with viscosity and potential
Burger’s equation (two-dimensional inviscid)—singularities (talk given at Columbia)
Gas Kinetic Theory in General (including Radiative Transfer)

Variational principle for Hamiltonian systems and vanishing Henyey determinant, [1980s?]
Duffing, van der Pol—high order approximation (rational approximation, [1980s?]
Fourier Pade equation ( (x..+x3=0), higher order correction
Pade: 2D: ordinary differential equations of higher order, 1D: quadratic, etc.
Rational approximation for a Hamiltonian system
Rational approximation for non-linear ordinary differential equations
Discussion on the paper “Rational Approximations for a Hamiltonian System”
Non-linear approximation for ordinary differential equation
Non-linear approximation for periodic orbits in a Hamiltonian System
Singular point approximation—solution of D.E. at an assumed pole, [1980s?]
Bifurcation and vanishing of Henyey matrix and other difference equations
“Implicit” form of solutions to ordinary difference equations
Talk on Non-linear mechanics (Fourier-Pade), New York University
Three-dimensional axisymmetric cylindrical beam scheme with body force
Numerical Navier-Stokes solution from gas-kinetic theory-K Xu, and K Prendergast
Numerical Navier-Stokes solution from gas-kinetic theory—Kun Xu and Kevin Prendergast
Paper II: KX and KHP Navier-Stokes Paper

Talk given at Supercomputer Conference, Santa Clara, 1989
Numerical hydrodynamics—talks at, Woods Hole & Columbia University, 7/25/2000 & 9/27/2000
